title: Do i need to pay the $800 minimum tax requirement to the franchise tax board pursuant to california revenue and taxation code?
question: good afternoon and hello from pomona,ca.i am just a new start up small business to be registered in the california state department as- limited liability company. i do research projects and my classification falls under professional, administrative and management services. assuming that i have no income, no projects for calendar year 2012, my question is -do i need to pay that minimum tax requirement for taxable year- 2013? if yes, why,please provide, specific tax section in the california revenue and tax code? if no, many thanks to the avvo lawyers who will be providing any such legal advice. if no, do i need to submit any tax form to the irs disclosing that i did not have any income/project for taxable year 2012?please provide tax form number if possible that i need to file, if any?
answers:
As a franchise attorney, I agree with the other attorney answers. The $800 minimum tax is exactly that - a minimum of $800 is due every year, whether the business has a loss or no income at all. It's basically for the privilege of operating a business entity in California. You may want to consider operating your company as s sole proprietorship. In that event, there is no $800 minimum tax payment.

Kevin B. Murphy, B.S., M.B.A., J.D.
Attorney at Law
Director of Operations - Mr. Franchise
FRANCHISE FOUNDATIONS APC

A limited liability company in California is subject to the $800 Minimum Tax each year and must file a tax return and pay this tax until it is dissolved. This is true even if the entity is inactive. See California Revenue and Taxation Code Section 17941 and 17942. If the LLC elects to be taxed as a partnership it must file Form 568, regardless if it is a disregarded entity.

Without insurance, your LLC will “protect” you from personal liability, even though you lose all the assets held by the LLC. Insurance can prevent virtually all loss to your net worth. Consult a business lawyer about this.
Your threshold question should be whether to form an entity (an LLC or an S Corp). It is a tradeoff between (1) unlimited personal liability and (2) paying to form the LLC and the taxes and fees payable by the LLC. (Consult a local lawyer as to his fees, state filing fees and taxes.) If risk is your main concern, the LLC is more advantageous; if costs, then a sole proprietorship.
Whether to incorporate is a question only you can answer. How risky do you think this business is? Incorporation protects your personal assets from creditors of the entity (i.e., the LLC or the corporation) but the entity remains liable for debts. The first thing to do is to get good liability insurance coverage–talk to a knowledgeable insurance agent. Also get professional responsibility (malpractice) insurance, as the LLC will not protect you there. Ordinarily the entity will not protect you from bank loans because the bank will require you to guarantee the loan personally. An LLC or an S corp will protect you from some of the liability while letting you deduct the business expenses on your personal tax return. An S corp has tricky rules for eligibility; if you lose the S corp treatment, the corp will become a C corp, liable for taxes on its income. This means double taxation. An LLC works just as well without the tax risk. If you transfer a building to a corp, you will regret it when it’s time to sell the building. You will be better off to buy liability insurance on the building and lease it to the LLC if you opt for an LLC.

As to your Q: If you decide you need protection, you should not wait till you have income. The work you do in 2013 could result in liability, even if you have no income.


B. Keith Martin
sbbizlaw.com

See the FTB website (link below), which in pertinent part states:
". . .Annual Tax
LLCs classified as disregarded or as partnerships are subject
to an $800 annual tax. This applies if they do business in
California or the SOS accepts their Articles of Organization
(LLC-1) or Application for Registration as a Foreign Limited
Liability Company (LLC-5). LLCs organized or registered in
California are subject to the annual tax even if they conduct
no business in California."

Why? because your state Government has laws and regulations that require it.

As my colleague advised, do not form you LLC if you do not have income and do not want to pay the $800 tax.

1. You have to pay the $800 min. tax regardless of the income/loss of the business.

I am not going to spend time looking up the code section as I know the answer is correct.

BW

You are required to pay the annual franchise tax fee of $800.00 every year. Do not apply for your LLC until you have the revenue to pay the fee. All the answers to your questions are in a publication from the FTB for the instructions to form 568 which is on the website of the FTB under "businesses."

You should consult with a tax attorney or an accountant before you appy for your LLC.
